steps.intro:
Welcome!

This self-paced tour will guide you, an Organization Administrator, through the process of creating new Customer Portal user accounts as well as assigning appropriate permissions for each.

To ensure the security of your organization's account and regulate user access to portal features, you or any other Organization Administrator must create a user login for each member of your organization.

Tip: A user account can only be associated with one organization. Users with existing accounts will need to be added as a new user to this account.
When logged in, you can access User Management from any page on the Red Hat Customer Portal by clicking your name then User Management in the Red Hat Account menu.

steps.title: User List
steps.intro: The User List page lists all users associated with your account. From here you can add new users to your account individually using the Add new user button or add multiple users using the Upload new users button.

steps.title: Add User
steps.intro:
Be sure to assign the appropriate permissions for the user under the "Customer Portal Access Permissions" section. Checking the Organization Administrator box under "Account Roles" will give the user all the permissions listed in the Customer Portal Access Permissions section.

Learn more about roles and permissionsâ€Œ.

steps.title: Bulk User Creation
steps.intro: Use the Upload new users button to add multiple users at once.

steps.title: Bulk User Upload
steps.intro:
Download and complete the .csv template (according to instructions included in the template) and then upload the file to have multiple users created at once.

Tip: To edit options for several users at once, select the appropriate users from the "User List" page and click "Edit." For more info on bulk editing see this instructional video.

Every individual within your organization should have his or her own unique user user account. For more information on the benefits of assigning individual user logins, reference this knowledge article.

Tip: In order to effectively and efficiently communicate with each member of your organization, a good best practice is to perform user management maintenance once every quarter.
